text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The response explicitly addresses the jurisdictional implications of the international contract and arbitration clause by referencing the New York Convention (NYC). In Section 1.D, the response states: \"Germany is a New York Convention state and generally arbitration-friendly: - If the defendant invokes the arbitration agreement, German courts typically must refer parties to arbitration unless the agreement is null/void/inoperative/incapable of being performed.\" This directly identifies that Germany, as a signatory state, is bound by the NYC's requirement to enforce written arbitration agreements contained in international contracts.", "criterion_id": "1eb4d20f-5462-487d-a69b-fed5c102d802"}
